title: Day 83 – Torrey, UT to Boulder, UT
content:
Back to the Chuck Wagon General Store for breakfast a little past 7am. The deli was open, so we had an unexpected hot meal - croissant egg sandwich for me, something else for Tess. The problem with waiting so long to post is that I forget crucial details like this. I’ll never know what Tess had for breakfast that day in Torrey…

After breakfast, Tess got talking on the porch with Jamison, who runs adventure tours when he’s not doing search and rescue missions in his home town of Zion National Park. He had a huge bin of snacks for his clients in his van and told us to take as much as we wanted. What a sweetheart!

We had forty miles to go that day, but a climb of over 4,000 feet over Boulder Mountain on Route 12. So whatever Tess ate, I hope it was enough fuel to sustain her. The ride started through rolling hills that reminded us a little of Italy. Cocks Comb stuck out behind the fields, reminding us we were still on the strange planet of Utah.

Traffic was pretty regular, and the grade got steep pretty quickly. It was feeling like Colorado again, but when we took little breaks we could spot the red cliffs of Capitol Reef below.

When we started getting up there in elevation we started seeing groves of aspens whose leaves had turned bright yellow. Out of nowhere a storm cloud came and started dropping freezing rain on us. We scrambled to get our gear all packed away in waterproof bags and booked it to get out from under the cloud and back into the sun.

We’d saved the Gifford cinnamon bun for the summit, and we were getting eager to finish our climb and sup on it. Right before the crest we passed a dead cow on the side of the road. I expect it’s a fairly common sight in the area, as it’s mostly open range. When we hit the summit I tore open the bag to get at the bun and took some selfies with it. A much larger storm was brewing to the east, so we didn’t have time to savor it but still enjoyed it.

We soon saw the beautiful sight of the sign warning trucks of the steep descent. We whizzed down the mountain in no time, but man was the air cold. We were pleased to enter the little town of Boulder.

Magnolia’s Street Food is a converted bus selling tasty food and coffee next to the Anasazi State Park Museum. Tess got some tacos and I got a burrito, and we each got an icy cold brew. It was a little overpriced but yummy.

The Airbnb we’d booked was a little south of the town, through cute farm roads that again reminded us of Europe except for the light-colored cliffs behind. The host Ellie wasn’t home when we arrived but left a welcome message for us as well as a hand-drawn breakfast menu for the next morning. It was a beautiful wooden cottage, and our room was large with possibly the most comfortable bed I’ve ever slept on. There were several cats roaming around outside. We showered and napped, listening to the sounds of the goats and chickens next door.

We’d considered treating ourselves to the highly recommended local farm-to-table restaurant Hell’s Backbone, but we didn’t really feel like leaving the cottage or spending the money (three dollar sign symbols on Google Maps). Instead we picked at the snacks we had in our orange food bag, and Tess made us wraps with peanut butter, dried fruit and sesame sticks. We sat out on the patio watching the horses run next door until it started to rain. Before bed we made some tea with honey and had no issue falling asleep.
